content.title: HTML Introduction
content.value:
HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language. It is the standard language for creating web pages. 
 HTML describes the structure of a webpage using markup. 
 It consists of a series of elements that tell the browser how to display content.

content.title: HTML Documents
content.value:
HTML is essential for web development. It allows you to create structured documents that can be displayed in web browsers. 

With HTML, you can:
- Create headings, paragraphs, links, images, and other content
- Structure your content with lists and tables
- Embed multimedia elements like videos and audio
- Create forms for user input

content.title: HTML Documents

All HTML documents must start with a document type declaration: <!DOCTYPE html>.
The HTML document itself begins with <html> and ends with </html>.
The visible part of the HTML document is between <body> and </body>.

CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets.
CSS saves a lot of work. It can control the layout of multiple web pages all at once.

content.title: What is CSS?
content.value: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets. With CSS, you can control the color, font, the size of text, the spacing between elements, how elements are positioned and laid out, what background images or background colors are to be used, different displays for different devices and screen sizes, and much more!

content.title: Using Css
content.value:
CSS can be added to HTML documents in 3 ways:
Inline - by using the style attribute inside HTML elements
Internal - by using a <style> element in the <head> section
External - by using a <link> element to link to an external CSS file
The most common way to add CSS, is to keep the styles in external CSS files. However, in this tutorial we will use inline and internal styles, because this is easier to demonstrate, and easier for you to try it yourself.

content.value: Links are found in nearly all web pages. Links allow users to click their way from page to page.

content.title: HTML Links - Hyperlinks
content.value:
HTML links are hyperlinks.
You can click on a link and jump to another document.
When you move the mouse over a link, the mouse arrow will turn into a little hand.

Note: A link does not have to be text. A link can be an image or any other HTML element!

content.title: HTML Links - Syntax
content.value: The HTML <a> tag defines a hyperlink. It has the following syntax:

content.title: Example
content.value: This is a link

The most important attribute of the <a> element is the href attribute, which indicates the link's destination.
The link text is the part that will be visible to the reader.
Clicking on the link text, will send the reader to the specified URL address.

content.title: HTML Links - Target Attribute
content.value:
By default, the linked page will be displayed in the current browser window. To change this, you must specify another target for the link.
The default value is _self, which means the linked document will open in the same window/tab as it was clicked.

Other values for the target attribute are:
- _blank: Opens the linked document in a new window or tab
- _parent: Opens the linked document in the parent frame
- _top: Opens the linked document in the full body of the window
